'''''Agaricus silvicola''''', also known as the '''wood mushroom''', is a species of [[Agaricus]] mushroom related to the [[button mushroom]].

==Taxonomy==
Originally [[species description|described]] as the [[variety (botany)|variety]] ''Agaricus campestris'' var. ''silvicola'' by [[Carlo Vittadini]] in 1832, it was promoted to distinct species status by [[Charles Horton Peck]] in 1873.<ref name="urlMycoBank: Agaricus silvicola">{{cite web|url= http://www.mycobank.org/BioloMICS.aspx?Table=Mycobank&Rec=768&Fields=All|title=''Agaricus silvicola'' (Vittad.) Peck|publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association|accessdate=November 11, 2012}}</ref>

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is light cream, and bruises yellow ochre when damaged. It is {{convert|5|–|10|cm}} in diameter, which makes it slightly smaller than its close relative ''[[Agaricus arvensis]]'', the "horse mushroom". The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is long, slim, and usually has a bulbous base. It is much the same colour as the [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], and has a fragile drooping [[annulus (mycology)|ring]]. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is thin and white, and smells of [[aniseed]].<ref name=Phillips06>{{cite book|author=Roger Phillips|year=2006|title =Mushrooms|publisher=Pan MacMillan|isbn=0-330-44237-6}}</ref> It looks fairly similar to a young [[death cap]].<ref name=mykoweb>{{cite web|url=http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Agaricus_silvicola.html|title=California Fungi—Agaricus silvicola|accessdate=January 18, 2008}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Agaricus silvicola'' grows in both [[deciduous]] and [[coniferous]] woodland in Britain, Europe, and North America.<ref name=Arora2nd>{{cite book|author=Arora, David|year=1986|title=Mushrooms Demystified|publisher=Ten Speed Press|isbn=0-89815-169-4|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0}}</ref> Appearing in the autumn, it is rarely seen in huge numbers, usually just a few, or solitary.<ref name=Phillips06/>

==Edibility==
It is [[edible mushroom|edible]] and popular in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtsn.tn.it/bresadola/gallery.asp?code=137&lang=eng |title=Agaricus sylvicola (Vittad.) Peck |accessdate=January 18, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606010226/http://www.mtsn.tn.it/bresadola/gallery.asp?code=137&lang=eng |archivedate=June 6, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grzyby.pl/gatunki/Agaricus_silvicola.htm|title=Agaricus silvicola (Vittad.) Peck (1887)|accessdate=January 18, 2008}}</ref> It is suspected to have caused an allergic reaction in a few people in North America.<ref name=mykoweb/>

==Similar species==
*''[[Agaricus osecanus]]''<ref name=Phillips06/>
*''[[Agaricus xanthodermus]]'' – the yellow stainer
*''[[Agaricus arvensis]]'' – the horse mushroom
*''[[Agaricus campestris]]'' – the field mushroom
